il.ac.technion.cs.sd.msg

Interface Messenger


  • public interface Messenger
    Allows passing messages between two different, possibly distributed, java applications. Each messenger has an address (getAddress()), that can be used to send it messages using send(String, String).
    Messages can only be retrieved using a Consumer.

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Abstract Methods Deprecated Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      String getAddress() 
      String getNextMessage(long timeoutInMillis)
      Returns the next received message.
      void kill()
      Stops the messenger; Killed messengers cannot accept new messages, but it is possible to create a new messenger with the same address as a killed messenger.
      void send(String to, String payload)
      sends a message to another messenger.
      void waitForMessage()
      Deprecated. 
      Relatively rare threading issues can cause uses to block indefinitely. For example, it is possible that the received message will be consumed before this method is called.
      If you wish to block until a message is received, it is best to use the consumer to funnel the messages to a BlockingQueue and wait on that (e.g., using Queue.poll() or BlockingQueue.poll(long, java.util.concurrent.TimeUnit)). You can also use getNextMessage(long)

    • Method Detail

      • kill

        void kill()
   throws MessengerException
        Stops the messenger; Killed messengers cannot accept new messages, but it is possible to create a new messenger with the same address as a killed messenger.
        Throws:
        MessengerException

      • getAddress

        String getAddress()
        Returns:
        the address of messenger

      • waitForMessage

        @Deprecated
void waitForMessage()
        Deprecated. Relatively rare threading issues can cause uses to block indefinitely. For example, it is possible that the received message will be consumed before this method is called.
        If you wish to block until a message is received, it is best to use the consumer to funnel the messages to a BlockingQueue and wait on that (e.g., using Queue.poll() or BlockingQueue.poll(long, java.util.concurrent.TimeUnit)). You can also use getNextMessage(long)
        Waits for a message to be received, which will be handled using the regular Consumer. This is a blocking call.
        Throws:
        RuntimeException - if killed while waiting

      • send

        void send(String to,
          String payload)
   throws MessengerException
        sends a message to another messenger. This method can fail for no reason. In case of failure, no indication will be given.
        Parameters:
        to - the address of the recipient of the message
        payload - the message's content
        Throws:
        MessengerException - Amongst other reasons, trying to send a non-ASCII string

      • getNextMessage

        String getNextMessage(long timeoutInMillis)
               throws InterruptedException
        Returns the next received message. It is suggested you call this method from the Consumer, to avoid race conditions. This message will not go through the consumer.
        Parameters:
        timeoutInMillis - The time to wait
        Returns:
        The message, if a message was intercepted in the alloted time (the message will not be consumed by the consumer); otherwise null.
        Throws:
        InterruptedException - If the messenger was interrupted during its wait
